label: What influences electric car battery performance?
desc: Hybrid and fully electric cars are awesome because they will help us save the planet from burning through more dinosaur juice! But temperature of the battery and the way of driving your car can influence the batteries performance.

label: Driving long-range
desc: During long-range driving, the car will mostly drive electrically and the battery will discharge slowly. Getting a high milage out of a single charge is key, so the State-of-Charge should remain constant as long as possible and only decrease slowly.

label: Driving sportively
desc: If you have a hybrid car and you drive it very fast (or 'sportively') the battery will heat up; after some 'boosts' of accellerating and breaking, the battery itself may not be able anymore to supply the full power. Your traditional fossil fuel engine will take over and re-charge the battery, increasing state-of-charge.

label: Driving in the winter
desc: The harshest test for a battery is driving in the winter. A cold battery cannot re-charge but will need to warm up first. It can do so by discharging while driving, but any energy fed back, e.g. from a generator in a hybrid engine or while breaking, will be lost.

label: Now it's your turn to explore!
desc: These three tests are standardized tests for any electric car battery. Automative manufacturers collect lots of metrics for each of those use cases. They even simulate those batteries in software. Now for each of the use cases, let's walk through such a simulation!
